sentence: And the framing is.

Imagine somebody went on a silent meditation retreat in 2021 and left thinking of Warp as that really cool terminal and Figma as that really cool design tool and reemerged today to enter a TechCrunch Disrupt.
How would it describe Warp today?
So Warp today still looks like a terminal.
You can use it as a terminal, but obviously the world has changed a bit in the last few years.
So the other thing you can do in Warp is instead of typing terminal commands, you can just interact with it in English.
And if you do that, it launches an agent.
So the way I would describe it today is a sort of general purpose interface for developers to ask the computer.
To do things for them.
Whether that's writing code or setting up projects or figuring out why your servers crash.
We sort of kept the roots of the app, but it has.
It just.
It was kind of a dream at the beginning because you talk this thing in English and now it's great that you can.
It's cool.
I'm not sure everyone realizes quite the scale of Warp.
Anything you can share about how many developers are using Warp like this.
So we have about 700,000 active developers in Warp recently.
We've been growing our revenue really fast too.
And it's all because of the.
This is sort of like crazy growth in productivity you get as a developer by being able to tell your computer to do things for you.
You great, Yuki.
I'm out of my style penetration retreat.
What's Figma?
Well, you know, back in 2021 we maybe were a single product company or maybe two products, figsum and sigma design.
And since then we have eight products.
And you know, what we've become is a company where you take an idea all the way to finished product in your user's hand.
So I think that's one big thing about our product, for teams to come back together, design, build and ship products.
And the other thing is, no, I think we still are a design tool in some ways, but we've expanded what design means.
You know, I think when people think of design, it's like drawing, you know, sketching, those kinds of visual manipulation is what we call it.
But we also believe that design can be accomplished via coding.
It can be accomplished via prompting.
So these are different mediums, if you will, that are available to help the ability of your products.
Great, let's stick with you.

So I think anybody who's interested in technology on the Internet probably has been reading like the Figma technical blogs for a long time and all the work you guys did to kind of bring collaboration into the browser.
There's enormous depth in Sigma and you take that depth and then apply AI.
And all the advances in AI talk a little bit about what it's like bringing AI into an ecosystem like figma, all the benefits, maybe the drawbacks and what that allows you to do for you.
Yeah, yeah.
It makes it hard.
Right.
Like we've been building a product for many years now.
In fact, we first launched in 2015.
Right.
And so we've been out there for 10 years and accumulated a lot of things.
And sometimes it's like adding.
You can think of it as well.
It's hard to just add this new thing on top of it and build it in this AI native way.

But, you know, one of the things I think was just interesting is we're really built with multiplayer from the ground up, meaning that, you know, we're thinking about collaboration from the very beginning.
So it's been interesting for us to bring AI into that equation.
And how do we take AI, which is often this very single player experience in many tools, into experience that makes it feel like AI is just yet another company.
So that's kind of our aspiration as we've been building, you know, a lot of our capabilities.
Same question for you, Zach.
Yeah, so we, you know, went through a bunch of iterations figuring out the right way to put AI into warp.
We did a thing initially, I think a lot of companies did.
We put a chat panel in and then we realized actually that integration doesn't.
Isn't necessary in the terminal, which is itself a sort of way of chatting with your computer.

And so the more like native, we've been able to make the AI feel like we got rid of that tap panel and you can just like I said earlier, instead of just entering terminal commands, you can just tell an agent to do something.
The more natural the interaction has been.
And so I think the key thing for us has been like, what's the most native way to get the AI into the workflow in our app?
That's been a big unlock.
Great.
Back to Yuki.
I think one trippy thing that I think about is like your team goes into work and fires up figma to load the next version of figma that uses figma to build figma and figma.
Maybe just talk about what it's like, your internal adoption of figma products and how your team has changed as you push the limits of creativity in figma.
Totally.
And what's that like?
Yeah, I mean it's kind of like inception in a way where we're like, what are we looking at?
Can you get rid of the other chrome so we can see just the design of figma outside of, without seeing the rest of figma really confusing.
But you know, I mean we're, we live and breathe Figma every single day.
And when I first arrived actually back in 2019, you know, we had this issue where my product managers were not using figma that much, right?
They're reviewing designs, doing all the PM things, but they weren't in it every single day.
And I think it's really important to be in your product every single day to really kind of, you know, build intuition, have a sense of quality.
And so, you know, were a very doc driven culture and we forced them to be a deck driven culture just so that they could be building decks in figma.
And now, you know, over time people are using it organically because we built a lot of tools for product managers and non designers like hdm, Sigma, Slides, Nick now.
So you know, it's made it a lot easier for people to have a bit more of an intuitive sense or feel connected to what they're building.
Figma.
Are, are people adopting the AI parts of figma internally to build figma?
Yeah, you know, we're trying to kind of, you know, we are, we have a lot of FIGMA make prototypes of figma make.
Okay.
And I think in today's world with prototype, with AI, you actually need to prototype with AI like an actual LLM to know what's possible, right?
As the prototypes are more important than ever before.
And for that, you know, we use Big O make and.
Was there any like change resistance or like stuff you had to do to get people to use it?
I asked if it warp.
It was at least initially challenging to get at least some of the more.
Senior and more experienced people on the.
Team to change their workload and be more AI first.
Yeah, I mean I think there are two kind of areas, right?

One is changing your workflow and for that, you know, and I'm not sure what the work equivalent would be, but for Figma design there are a lot of designers who want to code or who are dangerous enough to code some things but can't do everything.
And for them having this power of coding all of a sudden is really amazing.
And whether that's for three figure make, whether that's your work and so just kind of really pushing on that piece and getting people excited about that new capability.
And then the other Thing that was probably kind of a bit of attention is designers are very used to building the prototypes themselves and doing the designs themselves.
And all of a sudden you have a lot of other people kind of contributing to that process.

And while Figma has always been welcoming of that and blurring those boundaries, it's still a little bit kind of like strange when a PM shows up with a prototype of exactly what they were thinking of.

And I think that's something that culturally we just have to embrace a little bit more and say, okay, well what can designers do in that world where everyone's creating, what are the Rails that they can create?
The creative infrastructure of design systems that they can invest in so that everyone can create high quality stuff.
What's it like building Warp?
With Warp, it's, I mean, it's cool.
It's a huge productivity boost for the most part.
But like I was saying to Yuki, so it was actually, at least at the beginning, a little bit challenging to get the more senior developers on the team to adopt a new workflow.
So like, obviously there's a popularity of Vibe coding tools and like, I think a big part of the draw is like, if you're not a developer, you can build code, right?
You can write code, you can build apps.
For the senior developers on the team, it's like they know how to do it.
So it's not like a zero to one, it's more of like, how do It faster?

So we actually had to put in place a sort of mandate approach where every task within Warp should start with a prompt, doesn't necessarily need to finish with a prompt and doing that, obviously it's great for dog food feedback, that type of thing.
But we've gotten to a point now where it's interesting.

The more senior developers who are more reticent at first are now, I think, the most eager adopters and also the most skilled at actually guiding the agents to do coding tasks and sort of setting the new standard across the team for how you should work with the tool.
It's been cool.
Even in just like three to six months here, it's really changed internally.
